The abolition movement began as a result of the Age of Enlightenment (which was predominantly European), when ideas arose such as "natural rights" for all individuals. Slavery was also abolished in Europe first because they were less dependent on the system. That is also why the North abolished slavery before the South, there was very little demand for slave labor. There were also more outspoken abolitionists in England, particularly Granville Sharp and William Wilberforce.
